E*Trade Bootstrap

This version of Bootstrap has been customized and formatted to fit the E*TRADE brand and style guidelines. In fact, it's become the source of the style guidlines, as we build sites in code and not in Jpegs.

Documentation is in the docs folder, and all of that is generated into a styleguide visible at [http://styleguide.etradecreative.com] user: client password: Race2015!

Installation

Ideally this package should be a bower component, which pulls in its dependencies for development. However, you should be able to use this just by pointing at the css/etrade-bootstrap.css file, with the fonts folder and its contents as a sibling to the css folder. (This will allow the icon font to work). The CSS is compiled for every tagged release, so you don't have to recompile the source .scss files.

Git Flow

The eventual goal of this repo is to be the one truth for frameworks used across the E*Trade production environment and in prototypes as we work out how new components will interact with existing ones. To that end, we're aiming to use an adaptation of the Git Flow workflow to manage our branches in a sane way, and allow for code reviews, as well as having one place to manage conversations about components that is close to the code.

Branches

Master

This will be the main release branch, with production ready code. It will use Semantic Versioning for each commit, which will be a squash-merge of commits from other branches.

Development

This is the main branch that hosts development. New branches are created off this for work and labeled. You might, for example, have feature/{featureName}, bug/{bugName}, or prototype/{prototypeName}(see below). Once work on a feature or bug is complete, a pull request is created to merge it back in to the development branch. Commits to this branch should include cross browser solutions.

Prototype

While there's no permanent Prototype branch, the intention is to have a branch for each prototype that's being worked on, so that functionality can be added to the framework as needed without directly affecting the development branch. Prototypes can sometimes require more experimental features that aren't tested cross browser, so it's useful to have a branch that might not even be merged back in to development, but could be used as reference for adding individual features when a project moves to a proper development stage. This could happen either by cherry picking commits or reconstructing features on new feature branches once the requirements are better defined (as that's something that can get worked out in the process of prototype development).

Developing with other projects

You can use the bower link command to create a symlink to this repo when working in other projects so that you can see how the changes you make to this project affect other projects that have it as a bower dependency.

To accomplish this

  1. Clone this repo to your local machine
  2. From inside the project directory run $ bower link
  3. Run gulp watch inside this project to start watching for changes
  4. From any project that has this project as a dependency, run $ bower link etrade-bootstrap
  5. Any changes you make in this project will be reflected in the target project until the next time you run bower update

Working with the Style Guide

The styleguide is a static website built with harpjs.

npm install -g harp@0.15.2

Note there is an issue with the current versions of harp & node. Installing harp v0.15.2 resolves the issue

harp conventions used in the styleguide.

layouts

partials

metadata

excerpts

Generating docs

Styleguide source lives in the docs directory and gets copied to docs/dist. The gulp docs:build task will generate a new site.

Running a harp server during development

harp includes a server that's helpful to run while you're doing development. It handles the static site compilation without you needing to run a watch or build script.

cd docs && harp server --port 3000

Managing checking in compiled CSS

We're using this approach to manage compiled CSS in git. You have to go through this on your own development machine, as most of the steps here are changes to files that can't actually be checked in via git.
